summary: This is a memorandum opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's fourth motion in limine to exclude testimony from 'Witness-3' (Accuser-3). The court rules that portions of the witness's testimony are admissible as direct evidence for Mann Act counts and for permissible purposes under Rule 404(b), but imposes strict limitations to prevent unfair prejudice under Rule 403. The order includes proposed limiting instructions for the jury. This is a transcript of a pre-trial hearing in a criminal case (Case 1:20-cr-00084-AJN) before a judge. The discussion centers on the admissibility of testimony from witness Rasheen Vega regarding the victim's (Mr. Jones) medical condition and injuries following a shooting. The defense objects to graphic descriptions of bedsores and suffering, arguing it is prejudicial, while the prosecution argues it is necessary to establish causation of death. The judge sets limits on the testimony.

connections.description: Maxwell is alleged to have conspired with Epstein to recruit and facilitate sexual encounters with minors and young women.
Maxwell allegedly introduced Witness-3 to Epstein and facilitated their encounters, including providing a schoolgirl uniform and asking her to find other girls.
Witness-3 is expected to testify that she massaged Epstein while he was nude, and that these massages progressed to sexual activity.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and issuing rulings on evidentiary motions.
Mark DeMarco is the defense attorney for Ralph Berry in an unrelated murder case.
Ezra Spilke is a defense attorney for Ralph Berry in an unrelated murder case.
Rasheen Vega is the nephew of the victim, Mr. Jones, and was involved in his care after the shooting.
Mr. DeMarco is the defense attorney representing the defendant, Mr. Berry.
Mr. Hobson, the prosecutor, is preparing to call Rasheen Vega as a witness for the government.
They are opposing counsel in the criminal trial, debating the admissibility of evidence.

events.title: Pretrial Conference on Motion in Limine
events.description: Court heard argument on Maxwell's motion to exclude Witness-3 testimony. The court denied Maxwell's motion to preclude the government from referring to alleged victims as 'victims' but noted Witness-3 is not a victim of the charged crimes.

events.title: In Camera Hearing
events.description: Sealed hearing held pursuant to Federal Rule of Evidence 412 regarding the motion to exclude Witness-3 testimony.

events.title: Court Issues Memorandum Opinion & Order
events.description: Judge Nathan issues ruling on Maxwell's fourth motion in limine, partially granting and partially denying it, setting limits on Witness-3's testimony.

events.title: Alleged Start of Mann Act Conspiracies
events.description: The Mann Act conspiracies with which Maxwell is charged are alleged to have begun around this year.

events.title: Alleged Sex Trafficking Conspiracy Period
events.description: The charged sex trafficking conspiracy is alleged to have run from 2001 to 2004.

events.title: Shooting of Mr. Jones
events.description: Mr. Jones was shot, an event witnessed in part by his nephew, Rasheen Vega. The shooting caused paralysis.

events.title: Death of Mr. Jones
events.description: Mr. Jones died from sepsis, a complication stemming from bedsores and infections caused by paraplegia resulting from the 2000 shooting.

events.title: Pre-Trial Hearing on Testimony
events.description: A court hearing where the defense and prosecution argue over the admissibility of Rasheen Vega's graphic testimony about the victim's injuries and suffering.

locations: 500 Pearl Street (courthouse location mentioned in unrelated case transcript)
the alcove outside the jury assembly room
keyFacts: The court ruled that Witness-3's testimony is partially admissible as direct evidence for the Mann Act counts and for proving motive, intent, and knowledge under Rule 404(b), but not for the sex trafficking counts due to remoteness in time.

Witness-3 is expected to testify that Maxwell introduced her to Epstein, massages progressed to sexual activity, Maxwell provided a schoolgirl uniform, and Maxwell asked her to find other girls for Epstein.

The court imposed strict limits on the testimony: Witness-3 can state sexual activity occurred but cannot provide detailed descriptions, subjective experiences, or emotional impact, to minimize prejudice under Rule 403.
The government is prohibited from referring to Witness-3 as a 'victim' or 'minor victim' in front of the jury, as she was over the age of consent and not a victim of the charged crimes.

The court provided proposed limiting instructions for the jury, emphasizing that Witness-3's sexual conduct with Epstein was not illegal for the purposes of the indictment and cannot form the basis for conviction.
The case involves a shooting from June 2000 where the victim, Mr. Jones, was paralyzed and later died in November 2010 from complications.
A key issue is establishing legal causationâ€”proving the shooting directly led to the victim's death a decade later via paraplegia, bedsores, and infection.
The defense strongly objects to the nephew's (Rasheen Vega) graphic, non-expert testimony about oozing wounds and odor, arguing it is unduly prejudicial and meant to elicit jury sympathy.
The prosecution argues the testimony is crucial to connect the victim's post-shooting condition to his death, as medical experts did not observe him during the intervening decade.
The judge rules to allow limited, non-gratuitous testimony from Vega about the injuries but will strictly guard against overly emotional or graphic descriptions that could prejudice the jury.
